revision.text:
[[File:Bush hates Borf.jpg|thumb|right|"[[George W. Bush|Bush]] hates Borf" message painted on the Vision Lighting building near the [[Takoma (Washington Metro)|Takoma]] [[Washington Metro|Metro]] station. This message was changed to "[[Barack Obama|Obama]] Hates Borf" in 2009.]] [[File:Obama hates Borf.jpg|thumb|right|"[[Barack Obama|Obama]] hates Borf" message, which replaced the earlier message in 2009.]] '''Borf''' was a [[graffiti]] campaign seen in and around [[Washington, D.C.]] during 2004 and 2005, carried out by John Tsombikos while studying at the [[Corcoran College of Art and Design]]. This four letter word was ubiquitous around the [[Washington, D.C. (northwest)|Northwest]] quadrant of Washington, and ranged from simple tagging to complete sentences to two-color stencils to the massive defacement on an overhead exit sign from the [[Theodore Roosevelt Bridge]] to [[Constitution Avenue]].<ref name="Constitution">{{cite web |title = Borf's Magnum Opus? |date = April 19, 2005 |work = DCist |url = http://dcist.com/2005/04/borfs_magnum_op.php |accessdate = 2018-08-09 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180217181333/http://dcist.com/2005/04/borfs_magnum_op.php |archivedate = 2018-02-17 |deadurl = no }}</ref> Tsombikos was arrested on July 13, 2005 after tips led police to his latest tag.<ref name="Borf Arrest">{{cite news | first = Libby | last = Copeland | title = The Mark Of Borf | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/13/AR2005071302448.html | work = The Washington Post | page = C01 | date = July 14, 2005 | accessdate = 2007-03-11 }}</ref>
One of the most visible tags was the "BUSH HATES BORF" message painted above other graffiti on the back wall of the Vision Lighting Building and visible from the [[Red Line (Washington Metro)|Metro Red Line]] near the [[Takoma station|Takoma Metro station]]. This message was later replaced by a message saying "OBAMA HATES BORF" in early 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://ggwash.org/view/11799/obama-hates-borf-buffed-from-the-red-line |title="Obama hates BORF" buffed from the Red Line|publisher=Greater Greater Washington|author= John Muller |date=2012-02-08|accessdate=2009-08-11 |df= }}</ref> The graffiti was also reported to have appeared in [[New York City]], [[San Francisco]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dcist.com/archives/2005/04/13/borf_on_the_wes.php |title=Borf on the West Coast? |publisher=Dcist.com |date=2005-04-13 |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070407131425/http://www.dcist.com/archives/2005/04/13/borf_on_the_wes.php |archivedate=2007-04-07 |df= }}</ref> [[Raleigh, North Carolina]],<ref name="Sung 1">{{cite news|author=Ellen Sung |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/928/story/324689.html |title='Borf' is watching us, |publisher=Raleigh News & Observer |date= |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022205254/http://www.newsobserver.com/928/story/324689.html |archivedate=October 22, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="Sung 2">{{cite news|author=Ellen Sung |url=http://www.newsobserver.com/928/story/230481.html |title=Arrest may end artist's spree |publisher=Raleigh News & Observer |date= |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022205249/http://www.newsobserver.com/928/story/230481.html |archivedate=October 22, 2008 }}</ref> [[Rome, Italy]],<ref name="Rome">{{cite web |url=http://www.dcist.com/archives/2005/09/07/the_borf_saga_c.php |title=The Borf Saga Continues... In Rome |publisher=DCist.com |date=2005-09-07 |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019065524/http://www.dcist.com/archives/2005/09/07/the_borf_saga_c.php |archivedate=2006-10-19 |df= }}</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name="Global">{{cite web |url=http://www.dcist.com/archives/2006/10/12/borf_goes_globa.php |title=Borf goes global |publisher=DCist.com |date=2006-10-12 |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070214062855/http://www.dcist.com/archives/2006/10/12/borf_goes_globa.php |archivedate=2007-02-14 |df= }}</ref>
In 2009, director Paris Bustillos created a documentary film about the campaign entitled ''Borf!''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphoppress.com/2009/03/borf-and-chocolate-city-burning-a-private-screening-of-two-films-documenting-graffiti-culture-in-was.html |title=Borf! and Chocolate City Burning |publisher=hiphoppress.com | date=2009-03-16 |accessdate=2009-11-24}}</ref>
==Rationale== The campaign attracted widespread attention without first explaining its motivations. According to Tsombikos and subsequent Borf communiqués, both the nickname "Borf" and the Borf face belonged to Bobby Fisher, a close friend of Tsombikos' who had committed suicide.<ref name="libsyn1">{{cite web|url=http://dissonance.libsyn.com/ |title=Borf Brigade interview on Dissonance Radio |publisher=Dissonance.libsyn.com |date= |accessdate=2009-08-11}}</ref> In a video shown on July 29, 2006, the Borf Brigade – the group claiming responsibility for the graffiti spree – asserted that capitalism and the culture of aesthetics created alienation and feelings of worthlessness that contributed to the 16-year-old's suicide. The group said that they used other peoples' property to commemorate and pay homage to their deceased friend. The graffiti usually had overtones of anti-authority sentiments and [[Youth Rights|youth liberation]].<ref name="Communique">{{cite web | url = http://visualresistance.org/wordpress/2006/08/14/borf-brigade-communique/ | title = Borf Brigade Communique | accessdate = 2007-03-11 | date = August 14, 2006 | publisher = visualresistance.org }}</ref>
==Court appearance== Approximately four months after his arrest, Tsombikos appeared before the [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia]]. His paint-stained coat, which resembled one that he wore in [[Libby Copeland]]'s July 14 ''[[Washington Post]]'' article (published after his arrest), was declared evidence by the judge and handed over to the prosecution.
On December 12, 2005, Tsombikos agreed to plead guilty to one count of felony destruction of property. He also agreed to perform community service (cleaning up graffiti) and to pay $12,000 in restitution. Judge Leibovitz ordered him to stay out of the District except for court appearances and classes at the [[Corcoran College of Art and Design]].
On February 9, 2006, Tsombikos was sentenced to 30 days in the D.C. jail, with an additional 17 months suspended, as well as the community service and restitution specified in his plea agreement. At his sentencing, the judge said, "You profess to despise rich people. You profess to despise the faceless, nameless forms of government that oppress. That's what you've become. That's what you are. You're a rich kid who comes into Washington and defaces property because you feel like it. It's not fair. It's not right."<ref name="Sentencing">{{cite news | first = Henri | last = Cauvin | title = Borf Gets Month in Jail And Rebuke for Graffiti | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/09/AR2006020902273.html | work = [[The Washington Post]] | page = B09 | date = February 10, 2006 | accessdate = 2007-06-25 }}</ref>
==Communiqués== {{BLP sources section|date=July 2007}} At a [[Dupont Circle]] event after Borf's arrest, young people distributed spray paint and anarchist pamphlets.<ref name="Borf-In">[http://www.dcist.com/archives/2005/07/24/a_borf-in_at_du.php "A Borf-in at Dupont Circle", DCist.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019085916/http://www.dcist.com/archives/2005/07/24/a_borf-in_at_du.php |date=October 19, 2006 }}</ref> The following was distributed as a "communiqué" at the event:
{{quote|Borf is not caught. Borf is many. Borf is none. Borf is waiting for you in your car. Borf is in your pockets. Borf is running through your veins. Borf is naive. Borf is good for your liver. Borf is controlling your thoughts. Borf is everywhere. Borf is the war on boredom. Borf annihilates. Borf hates school. Borf is a four letter word for joy. Borf is quickly losing patience. Borf yells in the library. Borf eats pieces of shit like you for breakfast. Borf is digging a hole to China. Borf is bad at graffiti. Borf is ephemeral. Borf is invincible. Borf. Borf ruins everything. Borf runs near the swimming pool. Borf keeps it real. Borf writes you love letters. Ol’ Dirty Bastard is Borf. Borf knows everything. Borf is in the water. Borf doesn’t sleep. Borf systematically attacks the infrastructure of the totality. Borf is a foulmouth. Borf eats your homework. Borf brings you home for dinner. Borf is the dirt under your fingernails. Borf is the song that never ends. Borf gets down. Borf gets up. Borf is your baby. Borf is neither. Borf is good for your heart, the more you eat the more you. Borf is. Borf knows. Borf destroys. Borf is immortal. Borf pulls fire alarms. Borf scuffs the gym floor. Borf is looking through your mom’s purse. Borf is M. Borf is the size of Alaska. Borf likes pizza. Borf is in general. Borf is X. Borf ain’t nothin’ to fuck with. Borf runs it. Borf has reflexes like a cat. Borf is immortal. Borf sticks gum under the desk. Borf is omnipotent. Borf is flawed. Borf is winning.}}
On July 29, 2006, a group of young people calling themselves the "Borf Brigade" held a march in the [[Shaw, Washington, D.C.|Shaw]] neighborhood of Washington, and projected a "video communiqué" on a wall in which a young woman wearing a [[Zapatista Army of National Liberation|Zapatista]]-style face mask read a statement labeling Tsombikos a "minor Borfist" and announced that he had been "purged" from the group.<ref name="Communique" /> The video also said,
{{quote|On October 22, 2003, our friend Borf hanged himself from a basement pipe in a suburb of the nation's capital. This was not a solitary act. Over 30,000 people in the U.S. alone fall victim to this conspiratorial violence. It is the third leading killer of young people ages 15-24, and outnumbers homicides 3 to 2. This epidemic cannot be medicated into remission. It is not a problem confined to our family bloodline. "Trouble at home" is not the only trigger for depression.}}
==Consolation of Ruin art show== [[File:Bobby Fisher Memorial Building tag.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Borf piece on the side of the Bobby Fisher Memorial Building in Washington, D.C.]] In April 2007, wheat-pasted posters announcing a "BORF SHOW" slated for the weekends of May 18–20 and May 25–27 began appearing around Washington. The location was "The Bobby Fisher Memorial Building" at 1644 North Capitol Street NW.<ref name="libsyn1" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://borfyou.com/ |title=Borfyou.com |publisher=Borfyou.com |date= |accessdate=2009-08-11}}</ref><ref name="WP Borf">{{cite news | first = Libby | last = Copeland | title = The Borf Brigade Takes It Inside | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/24/AR2007052402465.html | work = [[The Washington Post]] | page = C01 | date = May 25, 2007 | accessdate = 2007-05-29 }}</ref>
The show, entitled "Consolation of Ruin" and sponsored by [[philanthropist]] Chuck Burgundy,{{citation needed|date=June 2009}} featured two floors of oil paintings, screen prints, etchings, installations, and video, all for sale in an effort to pay for Tsombikos' $12,000 restitution. One installation (a direct reference to Banksy's "[[elephant in the room]]" piece) was of a male figure hanging from a belt from the ceiling and painted to match the wallpaper designs on the wall, camouflaging the lifeless figure. A number of the original stencils used in the graffiti campaign were on display.<ref name="Indymedia Show">{{cite news | first = Mike | last = Flugennock | title = Borf Brigade's "Consolation Of Ruin" Opens at Bobby Fisher Memorial Building | url = http://dc.indymedia.org/newswire/display/139148/index.php | publisher = DC [[Indymedia]] | date = May 21, 2007 | accessdate = 2007-05-29 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130415031306/http://dc.indymedia.org/newswire/display/139148/index.php | archivedate = April 15, 2013 | df = }}</ref>
After the Borf show, the Bobby Fisher Memorial Building served as a youth-oriented space for music and art until its closing in July 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dcist.com/2008/06/26/the_house_that_borf_built_is_closin.php |title=The House That Borf Built is Closing |publisher=DCist |date=2008-06-26 |accessdate=2009-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081102213533/http://dcist.com/2008/06/26/the_house_that_borf_built_is_closin.php |archivedate=2008-11-02 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} * [[Banksy]] * [[Cool "Disco" Dan]] * [[Culture jamming]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category|Borf}} * [http://www.borfyou.com/ borfyou.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060303091459/http://visualresistance.org/wordpress/?p=94 Borf Interview ''Visual Resistance''] March 12, 2005 * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/22/AR2005072202231.html "We're all Borf in the end," ''The Washington Post''] July 24, 2005 * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/11/23/AR2005112302196.html?sub=AR "Borf Artist Dresses the Part for Court Appearance," ''The Washington Post''] November 24, 2005 * [http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/special/2006/borf0203.html "Borf Moves Up the East Coast," ''Washington City Paper''] February 3, 2006
{{DEFAULTSORT:Borf}} [[Category:American graffiti artists]] [[Category:Culture of Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Culture jamming]] [[Category:Anti-corporate activism]]

[[File:Cannabis Dispensary.jpg|thumb|Budtender handling cannabis at a dispensary in Colorado in 2018]] A '''budtender''' is a title of a staff member who works within a [[dispensary]] or store where medical or recreational [[cannabis]] is sold.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/lexicon_valley/2014/11/11/marijuana_legalization_and_language_budtenders_ganjapreneurs_420_joints.html|title=How Will Legalization Affect the Language Around Marijuana?|last=Dictionaries|first=Oxford|date=2014-11-11|work=Slate|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339}}</ref> Their job is to offer suggestions to customers, answer questions, handle products and showcase products being sold.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecannabist.co/2014/06/13/marijuana-terms-and-definitions-cannabis-lexicon-glossary-pot-terminology/13174/|title=The definitive cannabis lexicon: Marijuana terms from A-Z|date=2014-06-13|work=The Cannabist|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Origin == Budtender, a term recognized by [[Merriam-Webster]] as of March 2018,<ref name="MW">{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/budtender-as-marijuana-goes-legal-so-does-its-slang|title=As Marijuana Goes Mainstream, So Does Its Slang|publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]]|accessdate=April 3, 2018}}</ref> is a [[portmanteau]] that combines the word [[bartender]] and [[bud]]. Like a bartender, budtenders serve customers within a licensed establishment while the word bud is referring to the dried flower tops of Cannabis used for consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_basics.shtml|title=Erowid Cannabis Vault: Basics|website=www.erowid.org|access-date=2018-05-17}}</ref>
== Qualifications == The first budtenders gained knowledge through Cannabis farmers, extraction technicians, edible chefs and other cannabis experts.<ref name=":0" /> In the early days of legalized medical cannabis no prior schooling was needed to work as a budtender.<ref name=":1" /> As of 2017, no [[license]] or [[certification]] is needed to be a budtender.<ref name=":1" /> Because Cannabis is still illegal on a national level, no national licensing standards have been implemented.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecannabist.co/2017/07/19/marijuana-salesperson-budtender-license/83958/|title=Do you need a license or certificate to be a budtender (weed salesperson)?|date=2017-07-19|work=The Cannabist|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Most budtenders are self taught cannabis [[connoisseur]]s while some are trained formally. Training institutions include: Green CulturED, The Cannabis Training Institute, and Cannabis Trainers each with their own curriculum. For Green Cultured the total cost of the certifications is $119.00, Cannabis Training Institute is $299.00 for the program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecannabisreporter.com/want-budtender/|title=Want to Be A Budtender? Here's What You Need to Know|last=Bishop|first=Snowden|date=2016-05-19|work=The Cannabis Reporter|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> These institutions offer certifications in completed courses with subjects like [[Cannabis concentrate]]s, [[Cannabis consumption]], growing cannabis, cannabis laws and many more.<ref name=":0" /> Some courses are offered online while some are workshop that require physical attendance.
== Careers ==
=== Experience and knowledge === [[File:Cannabis Dispensary flower.jpg|thumb|right|Budtender behind a counter with various cannabis strains, 2018]]
Budtenders have to be qualified to work in a dispensary and must have a wide range of cannabis knowledge. In order to provide customers with a positive experience at a dispensary, budtenders need to demonstrate their knowledge of [[Cannabis strains|strains]], [[Cannabis edible|cannabis products]] and [[Medical cannabis|medical use]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.leafly.com/news/strains-products/budtender-product-spotlight-austin-tucker-dockside-cannabis-sodo-seattle|title=Budtender Spotlight: 5 Favorites From Dockside’s Austin Tucker {{!}} Leafly|date=2017-04-26|work=Leafly|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> They need to know the characteristics of each strain of cannabis they sell, based on their taste, smell and [[Effects of cannabis|effects]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.leafly.com/news/industry/how-to-get-hired-to-work-in-the-medical-cannabis-industry-part-2|title=How to Get Hired to Work in the Legal Cannabis Industry Part 2: Getting Hired as a Budtender {{!}} Leafly|date=2015-05-05|work=Leafly|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> If a customer were to ask about a specific strain that the dispensary does not have, a budtender should be able to recommend a similar strain with their broad understanding of cannabis in terms of the attributes of the customer’s original request. A budtender should also be able to adhere to the necessity for a medical marijuana user. Their ability to understand the medical circumstances of certain strains is critical and essential for the safety of the customer. Budtenders may stay aware of cannabis trends is by checking [[social media]] and industry [[blog]]s.<ref name=":2" />
=== Customer service === Since budtenders work one-on-one with customers, it is essential that they provide a welcoming environment for them. A budtender's job is to provide and share their knowledge of cannabis<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.leafly.com/news/industry/4-traits-of-a-bad-cannabis-budtender|title=4 Bad Budtender Habits that Consumers Notice (and Hate) {{!}} Leafly|date=2015-08-13|work=Leafly|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> with a customer, have the ability to teach those who have never tried cannabis before and to provide insight to new trends or strains. Budtenders also sometimes share stories<ref name=":2" /> in order to market to a customer and also to create a friendlier environment. These stories are meant to provide apprehension of what a customer might feel or do when they use a certain type of cannabis. However, budtenders are not recommended to push their products by telling fake stories and experiences in order to get a customer to buy something;<ref name=":2" /> this is considered bad customer service within the industry. Also, budtenders are commended when they have good hygiene when addressing or working with customers. Having clean hands and tidy attire<ref name=":2" /> are critical when a budtender works with a customer. Budtenders are also recommended to use tongs or gloves<ref name=":2" /> when pulling out a sample from a jar instead of reaching in with their bare hands. Finally, budtenders are also highly recommended to express a sense of passion for their product in order to spark interest from a customer.<ref name=":2" />
=== Income === Because the distribution and use of marijuana is illegal on a [[Federal government of the United States|federal level]], budtending salaries vary per state. However as of 2014, the general hourly income for a budtender is $11–12 per hour.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cannarecruiter.com/budtender-job-description/|title=Budtender Job Description: What is a Budtender? Qualifications Overview|date=2016-11-28|work=Canna Recruiter|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref> One of the perks of being a budtender is that many dispensaries give [[Discounting|discounts]]<ref name=":3" /> of their product to their employees. Budtenders will often get tips from their customers, and sometimes a yearly [[salary]] (with tips) can be from $31,000–$42,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cannabistraininguniversity.com/cannabis-job-salaries|title=Cannabis Job Salaries {{!}} Cannabis Training University|work=Cannabis Training University|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Legality == In the United States, there are 9 states that have legalized recreational marijuana, and another 21 states that have made medical marijuana legal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/where-can-you-can-legally-smoke-weed-2018-1|title=Here's where you can legally smoke marijuana in 2018|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref> Budtenders in these states are held to state legislation, and must comply with state law.
===Oregon=== Oregon, one of the 9 recreational marijuana states, is regulated by the [[Oregon Liquor Control Commission]] (OLCC), and require all budtenders to be at least 21 years or older to obtain a license and or permit.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oregon.gov/olcc/marijuana/Documents/Marijuana_Worker_Permit/MJ_WorkerPermitEducation_English.pdf|title=Recreational Marijuana Worker Permit Education|last=|first=|date=May 21, 2018|website=www.oregon.gov|archive-url=http://www.oregon.gov/olcc/marijuana/Documents/Marijuana_Worker_Permit/MJ_WorkerPermitEducation_English.pdf|archive-date=July 1, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Whether it be production or processing purposes, any budtender who actively handles marijuana, must have a permit to secure or sell marijuana items.<ref name=":4" /> Having these permits is necessary under Oregon law, however; permits are only valid for five years from the date issued by the OLCC. All permits under the commission grant an employee access to any licensed marijuana business in the state.<ref name=":4" /> Being a fairly regulated business, all budtenders are required by state law to have their worker permits readily available at any time while working, in case of immediate inspection by OLCC regulatory staff or enforcement officer.<ref name=":4" /> It is advised to keep the permit on one's self when working, for this immediate reason. If a budtender who possesses a legal permit were to be convicted by the state for misdemeanor or felony, they have 10 days to submit a written notification to the Commission.<ref name=":4" /> No permit is transferable; the permit to sell recreational marijuana belongs to the permittee.<ref name=":4" /> The only applicable license type that allows the sale of marijuana items to a consumer is the retail license. Every retailer must verify the age of every customer, for any and all purchases, and can only sell between the hours of 7am-10pm.<ref name=":4" /> A budtender cannot offer free samples to customers, give free marijuana items, or provide any form of discount if the sale is inline with the sale of other items. Retailers may only receive marijuana products from the OLCC licensed producers, processors, and wholesalers.<ref name=":4" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Cannabis}} *{{Commons category inline|Budtenders}}

page.title: Cement industry in the United States

revision.text:
The '''cement industry in the United States''' produced {{convert|82.8 |e6t}} of [[cement]] in 2015, worth US$9.8 billion, and was used to manufacture concrete worth about US$50 billion. The US was the world's third-largest producer of cement, after [[Cement industry in China|China]] and [[India]]. The US [[cement industry]] includes 99 [[cement mill]]s in 34 states, plus two plants in [[Puerto Rico]]. The industry directly employed 10,000 workers in 2015. Ten percent of the cement used in the United States in 2015 was imported.<ref name="Summary">US Geological Survey, [http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/cement/ Cement], Mineral Commodity Summary, 2016.</ref>
==Uses== The types and amounts of cement produced in 2015 were: * [[Portland cement]] 80.4 million tons * Masonry cement 2.4 million tons * Other [[hydraulic cement]] 0.6 million tons
Cement production is predominantly [[portland cement]], which is mostly used in concrete. Cement for concrete is an essential material for construction, and demand is a function of construction spending. Single-family residential construction is considered only moderately cement-intensive; multifamily residential somewhat more intensive. Nonresidential construction and government construction projects are considered the most cement-intensive.
In 2013, 70.8 percent of portland cement was sold as [[ready-mix concrete]], such as is delivered in cement-mixer trucks. 11.5 percent was sold dry to contractors and construction materials stores; 11.3 percent was sold to manufacturers of concrete products; 4.6 percent was sold for oil and gas wells, and 1.8 percent was sold to government agencies and others.<ref name="Yearbook">US Geological Survey, [http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/cement/myb1-2013-cemen.pdf Cement], Minerals Yearbook, 2013.</ref>
==Geography== Because cement is a bulk commodity, transportation can be a significant part of the cost. To minimize transportation costs, cement plants are ideally located close to the market, with access to efficient transportation such as ship or railroad. Most cement plants are located close to the limestone deposits.
Thirty-four states have cement manufacturing plants. In 2013, the five leading cement-producing states, in descending order, were: [[Texas]], [[California]], [[Missouri]], [[Florida]], and [[Alabama]]. Together, the five accounted for almost half of US cement production. The list of top five cement-consuming states is similar: Texas, California, Florida, [[Ohio]] and [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Yearbook"/>
In 2015, about 10 percent of US cement consumption came from imports. The largest sources of US cement imports were [[Canada]] and [[Greece]].<ref name="Summary"/>
==Industry structure== In 2013, the top producers of portland cement in the US were:<ref name="Yearbook"/>
* 1 - [[CEMEX]] * 2 - [[Holcim]] (now [[LafargeHolcim]]) * 3 - Lehigh Hanson Inc. * 4 - [[Buzzi Unicem]] * 5 - [[Ash Grove Cement Company]] (to be acquired by [[CRH plc]] in early 2018) * 6 - [[Lafarge North America]] (merged with Holcim in 2015) * 7 - [[Texas Industries Inc]] * 8 - Eagle Minerals Inc. * 9 - Essroc Cement Corp. * 10 - St. Marys Cement Group
In 2013, the top 5 companies produced 54 percent of US portland cement; the top 10 companies produced 78 percent.
==Inputs== Portland cement is a complex mixture, mostly calcium, with admixtures of aluminium, silica, and iron. The choice of source materials depends on local availability. The calcium is usually supplied by limestone, but sometimes shell or coral. Slightly clayey limestones are preferable, because they already contain the necessary aluminium. Cement cannot contain more than 5 percent magnesium, so the limestone must be low in magnesium.
'''Raw materials used in US cement production, 2013''' {| class="wikitable sortable sortable" ! style="background:#DDDDFF;" | Input ! style="background:#DDDDFF;" | million metric tons |- | align=center | Limestone, shell, coral | align=right | 91.5 |- | align=center | Cement rock | align=right | 9.4 |- | align=center | Gypsum | align=right | 4.0 |- | align=center | Clay | align=right | 3.3 |- | align=center | Sand | align=right | 3.1 |- | align=center | Fly ash | align=right | 2.7 |- | align=center | Shale | align=right | 2.1 |- | align=center |Imported clinker | align=right | 1.3 |- | align=center | Other ash | align=right | 1.0 |- | align=center | All other materials | align=right | 5.5 |- | align=center | '''Total''' | align=right | '''123.9''' |- ! colspan=3 style="font-weight: normal; font-size: 0.9em; text-align: left; padding: 6px 2px 4px 4px;" | Source: US Geological Survey, Minerals Yearbook, 2013.<ref name="Yearbook"/> |}
Energy sources used in the US to manufacture cement in 2013 were: * Coal 6.0 million metric tons * Petroleum coke 1.6 million metric tons * Solid waste 1.1 million metric tons * Used tires 0.4 million metric tons * Oil 15.7 million liters * Liquid waste 0.8 million liters * Natural gas 694 million cubic meters * Electricity 10.5 billion kilowatt-hours
==Environmental Effects== The cement industry has both positive and negative effects on the environment.
===Source of waste and pollutants=== Cement manufacture is a source of the following airborne contaminants: particulate matter, nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, and carbon dioxide.<ref>[https://www3.epa.gov/ttnchie1/ap42/ch11/final/c11s06.pdf Cement manufacture], US EPA, accessed 1 June 2016.</ref>
Cement production releases carbon dioxide by [[sintering]] limestone or shells. It is also very energy-intensive, with the result that the cement industry is a large emitter of carbon dioxide.
===Destruction of waste and pollutants=== The high temperatures of [[cement kiln]]s, the ability of concrete to incorporate different materials, and the stable and nonreactive nature of the concrete end product, all make cement kilns a desirable method for the destruction of hazardous waste.
Hazardous wastes efficiently destroyed by cement kilns include chlorinated solvents ([[methylene chloride]], [[trichloroethylene]], [[trichloromethane]], [[trichloroethane]], [[carbon tetrachloride]]), [[Freon]]-113, [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s (PCBs), [[dioxin]], waste oil, and used hydrocarbon solvents. Whatever undesirable materials are not destroyed are locked in the finished concrete, a stable material with low permeability. Hydrocarbon waste and used tires contribute to the kiln heat, and reduces fuel use. <ref>[https://www3.epa.gov/trimewebhelp/test/WebHelp.1282016/section_4_5_3_cement_kilns_burning_hazardous_waste_as_supplemental_fuel.htm "Cement kilns burning hazardous waste as supplemental fuel], US Environmental Protection Agency, accessed 2 June 2016.</ref>
In addition to destruction of hazardous waste, waste materials from other industries, such as slag and fly ash, are commonly incorporated into cement, eliminating the need to landfill the waste.<ref>[http://industrialresourcescouncil.org/Applications/PortlandCementManufacturing/tabid/384/Default.aspx Portland cement manufacturing], Industrial Resources Council, accessed 1 June 2016.</ref> The ability of cement to incorporate different materials allows contaminated soil to be added to the feed, eliminating the need to take the material to a hazardous waste landfill. The US EPA estimated that in 2014, 13.1 million tons of coal fly ash, which otherwise would have to be landfilled, was beneficially used in cement.<ref>[https://www.epa.gov/coalash/coal-ash-reuse< Coal as reuse], US EPA, 24 June 2016.</ref> In addition, the use of fly ash improves the strength and durability of concrete<ref>[https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/pavement/recycling/fach03.cfm Fly ash concrete for highways], US Dept. of Transportation, accessed 13 July 2016.</ref>
== See also == * [[American Concrete Institute]] * [[Portland Cement Association]] ==Citations== <references/>
[[Category:Cement industry]]

{{Infobox non-profit | name = Cortex Innovation Community | image = [[Image:Cortex_Innovation_Community_Logo.png]] | caption = | founder = [[Washington University]], [[BJC HealthCare]], [[University of Missouri – St. Louis]], [[St. Louis University]], and the [[Missouri Botanical Garden]] | type = Tax-exempt 501(c)3 Non-profit | tax_id = | registration_id = | founded_date = {{Start date|2002}} | location = [[Midtown St. Louis|Midtown neighborhood]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.63465415|-90.25115899250936|dim:1000_region:US-MO|display=title}} | origins = | key_people = Henry Webber, Chairman; Dennis Lower, President and CEO, [[William Henry Danforth]], [[John Dubinsky]]<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution2">{{cite web| url=http://eqstl.com/conceiving-cortex-cortex-special-feature-chapter-1-2000-2002/ | title=Conceiving Cortex: Cortex Special Feature, Chapter 1, 2000-2002| first=Mary | last=Mack | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=27 February 2017 | work=EQSTL }}</ref><ref name="bizjournal-dubinsky">{{cite web| url=https://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/print-edition/2012/11/30/john-dubinsky.html | title=John Dubinsky | first=Greg | last= Edwards | accessdate=20 September 2018 | date=30 November 2012 | work=[[St. Louis Business Journal]] }}</ref><ref name="stifel-dubinsky">{{cite web| url=https://www.stifel.com/investor-relations/board-of-directors/john-p-dubinsky | title=Stifel Official Bio | accessdate=20 September 2018 }}</ref> | area_served = [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], [[United States]] | products = | services = | focus = [[Land use]], [[land development]], [[redevelopment]], [[placemaking]], [[marketing]], [[startups]], [[financing]] and [[fundraising]]. | mission = Turn an old industrial area into a dynamic development with economic growth from increasing people and business interactions. | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 11 | num_members = 22 directors<ref name="brookings-stl" /> | subsid = | owner = | motto = | former name = Cortex West Redevelopment Corporation | homepage = https://cortexstl.com | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Cortex Innovation Community''', '''Cortex Innovation District''', or '''Cortex''' is an [[innovation district]] in [[St. Louis|Saint Louis]].<ref name="cortex-official">{{cite web| url=https://cortexstl.com | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Cortex Official Website }}</ref> Cortex is a 200-acre hub of technology and biological science research, development, and commercialization.<ref name="ninenet-oral">{{cite web| url=http://www.ninenet.org/cortex-archive/ | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Cortex - Oral History | date=28 August 2018 }}</ref> It anchors St. Louis startup technology companies in the city.<ref name="cortex-thedistrict">{{cite web| url=https://cortexstl.com/the-district/ | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Cortex Official The District }}</ref><ref name="forbes-stl">{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/williamarruda/2017/12/05/what-to-look-for-in-a-city-when-youre-relocating-for-work/#3f6708d467ad | title=What To Look For In A City When You're Relocating For Work | first=William | last=Arruda | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=5 December 2017 | work=Forbes }}</ref>
Cortex states that once their master plan is completed, there will be $2.3 billion of construction and more than 4.5 million square feet of mixed-use development, including 13,000 jobs in technology.<ref name="cortex-thedistrict" /><ref name="stlpublicradio-aloft" /><ref name="brookings-stl" />
The current initiative for Cortex is called Cortex 3.0, $170 million expansion of Cortex to be completed in fall 2018.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution">{{cite web| url=http://eqstl.com/cortexs-evolution-life-science-district-magnet-st-louis-innovators-feature-series/ | title=Cortex’s Evolution From A Life Science District To A Magnet For St. Louis Innovators: A Feature Series | first=Mary | last=Mack | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=27 February 2017 | work=EQSTL }}</ref><ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution4">{{cite web| url=http://eqstl.com/cortexs-evolution-life-science-district-magnet-st-louis-innovators-feature-series/ | title=Cortex Looks Ahead: Cortex Special Feature, Chapter 4, 2017 And Beyond | first=Mary | last=Mack | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=2 March 2017 | work=EQSTL }}</ref>
== History ==
In 1998, [[William Henry Danforth]], whom 3 years prior had retired as chancellor of [[Washington University]] in St. Louis, recognized that the region was not building upon its core strengths in medicine and plant sciences. He formed the Coalition for Plant and Life Sciences, now known as [[BioSTL]].<ref name="ninenet-oral" />
This eventually led to the creation of the [[Donald Danforth Plant Science Center]].
Coming off that successful project, [[William Henry Danforth]] and [[John Dubinsky]], CEO of financial consulting firm [[Westmoreland Associates]] and the eventual chairman of the Cortex board, went to Cambridge to study [[Kendall Square]], the most notable [[innovation district]] to see how the concept could be used in St. Louis.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution2" />
The idea for Cortex came from the idea to create a district where companies could have a presence with access to talent, new technology, labs and intellectual property in order to innovate. The reason the [[Midtown St. Louis|Midtown neighborhood]] was selected for the location of Cortex is because the founding institutions are nearby and the Millenial Generation showed desire to live and work in the nearby urban areas.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution2" /><ref name="curbed-millenials">{{cite web| url=https://www.curbed.com/2018/8/7/17658662/university-real-estate-development-startup| accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Universities, chasing the startup economy, reshape urban real estate | first= Patrick | last=Sisson | date=7 Aug 2018 }}</ref><ref name="brookings-stl" />
Cortex as an organization was founded in 2002 by [[Washington University]] (WashU), [[BJC HealthCare]] (BJC), [[University of Missouri – St. Louis]] (UMSL), [[St. Louis University]] (SLU), and the [[Missouri Botanical Garden]].<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution2" />
Cortex is a 501(c)3 tax-exempt organization.<ref name="cortex-whoweare">{{cite web| url=https://cortexstl.com/who-we-are/ | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Cortex Official Who We Are }}</ref><ref name="brookings-stl" />
To start the initial nonprofit to purchase land, members contributed $29 million USD as collateral for loans and purchasing of land. Washington University provided $15 million, BJC and SLU gave $5 million each, and UMSL gave $4 million USD.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution2" />
The Cortex West Redevelopment Corporation was classified by the city under Missouri statute Chapter 353, as a master developer of the district. St. Louis Mayar [[Francis Slay]] gave Cortex the ability to redevelop the area broadly in the "public interest" with the tools of issuing tax abatements and using [[eminent domain]] if necessary, as has been documented as least two times.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution2" /><ref name="brookings-stl" />
The first hire by Cortex was CEO, Dennis Lower. Lower executed a plan called Cortex 2.0 and converted Cortex from a bioscience district to an open mixed-used district. Also part of Cortex 2.0 was a shift to startup technology companies.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution3">{{cite web| url=http://eqstl.com/cortexs-evolution-life-science-district-magnet-st-louis-innovators-feature-series/ | title=Cortex Shifts Focus: Cortex Special Feature, Chapter 3, 2010-2016 | first=Mary | last=Mack | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=1 March 2017 | work=EQSTL }}</ref>
In summer of 2014, [[Square, Inc.|Square]], the payments company setup by St. Louis natives [[Jim McKelvey]] and [[Jack Dorsey]] opened offices at Cortex 4240.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution3" />
In 2015, [[Ikea]] opened in Cortex.<ref name="eqstl-cortex-evolution3" />
In 2018, [[Microsoft]] opened its first midwest headquarters in Cortex building 4220.<ref name="curbed-millenials" />
In Fall 2018, once [[Venture Cafe|Venture Cafe Innovation Hall]] opens at the 4220 Building in Cortex, 23 City Blocks Hospitality Group's restaurant and cafe, The Chocolate Pig will open.<ref name="feast-chocopig">{{cite web| url=http://www.feastmagazine.com/the-feed/st_louis_news/article_e7ee9272-3d93-11e8-b775-b773792b4624.html | title=The Chocolate Pig to Open at Cortex Innovation Hall This Fall | first=Nancy | last=Stiles | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=11 April 2018 | work=Feast Magazine }}</ref>
In June 2018, [[Aon (company)|AON]] announced it was relocating 200 of its employees to the Cortex new 4220 building.<ref name="stltoday-aon">{{cite web| url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/aon-relocating-employees-from-clayton-to-st-louis-cortex-district/article_04bcae19-7754-5009-8ed4-0836c00cca0f.html | title=Aon relocating 200 employees from Clayton to St. Louis' Cortex district | first=Brian | last=Feldt | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=8 June 2018 | work=[[St. Louis Post Dispatch]] }}</ref>
== Location ==
The Cortex Innovation Community is located in the [[Midtown St. Louis|Midtown neighborhood]]. It is over 200 acres of land and is situated nearby St. Louis’ [[Central West End]] and [[Forest Park (St. Louis)|Forest Park]] neighborhoods. It is next to internationally known [[Washington University]], its medical campus, [[St. Louis University]], and [[Barnes-Jewish Hospital]]. Cortex is near cultural institutions including the [[Grand Center Arts District, St. Louis|Grand Center Arts District]] and the [[Missouri Botanical Garden]]. Cortex is next to [[Forest Park (St. Louis)|Forest Park]], which is home to the [[St. Louis Zoo]], the [[St. Louis Art Museum]], the [[St. Louis Science Center]], the [[Missouri History Museum]].
== Construction ==
One of the primary companies building Cortex is Wexford. They have developed 3 properties and a total of 536,903 square feet.<ref name="wexford-cortex">{{cite web| url=http://wexfordscitech.com/projects/cortex/ | title=Wexford + Cortex | accessdate=19 September 2018 }}</ref>
== Milestones ==
* 1.7 million square feet completed or in-development. * Credited for $500 million of investment in the last 14 years and making 3,800 technology jobs.<ref name="brookings-stl">{{cite web| url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/metropolitan-revolution/2016/05/05/in-st-louis-a-gateway-to-innovation-and-inclusion/ | title=In St. Louis, a gateway to innovation and inclusion | first=Julie | last=Wagner | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=5 May 2016 | work=Brookings }}</ref> * Installation of MetroLink light-rail station called "Cortex Station"<ref name="wustl-metro">{{cite web| url=https://source.wustl.edu/2018/07/cortex-metrolink-station-to-open-july-31/ | title=Cortex MetroLink Station to open July 31 | accessdate=18 September 2018 | author=Diane Toroian Keaggy | date=24 July 2018 | work=Washington University The Source }}</ref><ref name="metro-official">{{ref web| url=http://www.metrostlouis.org/nextstop/metro-announces-opening-date-for-cortex-metrolink-station/ | title=Metro Announces Opening Date for Cortex Metrolink Station | accessdate=18 September 2018 }}</ref><ref name="stlpublicradio-metro">{{ref web| url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/cortex-metrolink-stop-opens-promises-tech-job-growth#stream/0 | title=Cortex MetroLink stop opens with promises of tech job growth | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=31 July 2018 | author=Kae M. Petrin }}</ref> * Over 370 companies based in Cortex.<ref name="brookings-stl" />{{Citation needed|reason=Fact changed by anon ip but, no reference to support the claim.|date=September 2018}} * Addition of new building 4220 a $53 Million building includes [[Microsoft]] and [[Venture Cafe|Innovation Hall]], a 13,800-square-foot space based upon [[Venture Café|Venture Café’s]] District Hall in Boston.<ref name="stltoday-4220">{{cite web | url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/developer-plans-more-buildings-in-st-louis-booming-cortex-innovation/article_a5a0a77d-b077-51c6-8627-1df0e0fe49fb.html | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=13 April 2018 | first=Brian | last=Feldt | title=Developer plans more buildings in St. Louis' booming Cortex innovation district }}</ref><ref name="rejournal">{{cite web| url=https://www.rejournals.com/tarlton-overseeing-construction-of-st-louis-innovation-hall-20180907| work=rejournal | title=Tarlton Overseeing Construction of St. Louis Innovation Hall | accessdate=18 September 2018 }}</ref> * Aloft hotel under construction, a $25 million USD hotel with 129 rooms.<ref name="stlpublicradio-aloft">{{cite web| url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/aloft-hotel-breaks-ground-cortex | title=Aloft Hotel Breaks Ground in Cortex | accessdate=18 September 2018 }}</ref><ref name="stltoday-cortexdevs">{{cite web | url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/new-million-cortex-development-to-add-hotel-apartments-parking-garage/article_3ca0ad4a-ab02-5c5e-9c5b-f16d6a51a374.html | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=20 October 2016 | author=Jacob Barker | author2=Tim Bryant | title=New $170 million Cortex development to add hotel, apartments, parking garage }}</ref> * Phase one of a five level parking garage started in Fall 2018 for $14.7 million USD.<ref name="ksdk-cortex-parking">{{cite web| url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/aloft-hotel-breaks-ground-cortex | title=Work starts on parking garage at Cortex | accessdate=18 September 2018 | date=13 August 2018 }}</ref> * [[Esri]] expanded its presence in St. Louis at Cortex to service their major client [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] who is opening their [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency|Next NGA West]] campus in the near future.<ref name="esri-office">{{cite web| url=http://www.esri.com/esri-news/releases/18-2qtr/esri-expands-st-louis-office-to-new-space-in-tech-district | title=Esri Expands St. Louis Office to New Space in Tech District | accessdate=19 September 2018 | date=30 May 2018 }}</ref><ref name="next-nga-official">{{cite web| url=http://nextngawest.com | title=Next NGA West | accessdate=19 September 2018 | work=Next NGA West Official Site }}</ref>
== Innovation Centers ==
=== CET St. Louis ===
The Center for Emerging Technologies (CET) is developing and establishing next-generation biomedical science and other advanced technology companies.<ref name="cortex-thedistrict" /><ref name="cet-official">{{cite web| url=https://cetstl.com | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Center for Emerging Technology }}</ref>
=== BioGenerator ===
BioGenerator discovers technologies and services with potential with an academic, research or entrepreneur to make a company.<ref name="cortex-thedistrict" /><ref name="biogen-official">{{cite web| url=http://biogenerator.org | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=Biogenerator }}</ref>
In 2018, BioGenerator announced they will anchor the new Cortex biotech building.<ref name="stltoday-biogen-anchor">{{cite web| url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/biogenerator-plans-to-anchor-cortex-biotech-building/article_98c5e3a4-5e1a-5024-bbbd-f25595fd8a06.html | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=BioGenerator plans to anchor Cortex biotech building | work=[[St. Louis Post Dispatch]] | first=Jacob | last=Barker | date=18 April 2018 }}</ref>
=== CIC St. Louis ===
[[Cambridge Innovation Center]] (CIC) provides services for startups and companies including innovations spaces and [[coworking]]. CIC supports innovation in public relations, law, education, technology and life sciences.<ref name="cortex-thedistrict" /><ref name="cic-official">{{cite web| url=https://cic.com/stlouis | accessdate=18 September 2018 | title=CIC Official }}</ref>
=== Venture Cafe St. Louis ===
[[Venture Café|Venture Café St. Louis]] is a nonprofit hosting community-focused events and programs which support early-stage entrepreneurs.<ref name="cortex-thedistrict" />
==See also==
* [[Cambridge Innovation Center]] * [[Venture Café]]

[[File:David Jones 2014.jpg|thumb|David Jones at [[One Young World]] 2014]] {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''David Robert Jones''' (born 9 November 1966) is a former CEO of [[Havas]] and [[Havas Worldwide]] (formerly known as [[Euro RSCG Worldwide]]), and cofounder of global youth forum [[One Young World]]. He is author of ''Who Cares Wins: Why Good Business Is Better Business''<ref name="amazon1">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Who-Cares-Wins-business-Financial/dp/0273762532 |title=Who Cares Wins: Why good business is better business (Financial Times Series) (9780273762539): David Jones: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date=9 September 2009 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> (Pearson/FT Publishing, November 2011) and the creator of the "Social Business Idea".
==Career== David Jones was born and educated in North West England and holds business degrees from [[Reutlingen University|Fachhochschule Reutlingen]] and [[Middlesex Business School]]. Fluent in German, French and English, he began his career as an account executive at [[BDH Manchester]] (now [[TBWA]]) before moving to [[J. Walter Thompson|JWT]] in Paris and then [[Lowe Europe]]. Returning to London, he became the youngest board member at [[AMV BBDO]].
Jones' career with Havas began in 1998, when he was appointed CEO of Euro RSCG Australia at age 32. After launching the network's first digital agency, he became president of global brands for Euro RSCG Worldwide and served as global brand director on [[Reckitt Benckiser]]. In 2004 he was promoted to CEO of Euro RSCG New York and in 2005 he succeeded Jim Heekin as CEO of Euro RSCG Worldwide and also taking on duties as directeur general of Havas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.media-online.ru/eng/index.php3?id=23806 |title=Euro Rscg Chairman-Ceo Resigns |publisher=Media-online.ru |date=2 August 2005 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> In 2006 Euro RSCG became the first agency to be named Global Agency of the Year by both [[Advertising Age]] and [[Advertising campaign|Campaign]] in the same year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/news/global-agency-network-year-euro-rscg/114126/ |title=Global Agency Network of the Year: Euro RSCG | News – Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=8 January 2007 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/610113/ |title=The Annual 2006: Advertising Network of the Year – Euro RSCG | Advertising news | Campaign |publisher=Campaignlive.co.uk |date=15 December 2006 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> In 2009, Jones added the title of CEO of Havas Worldwide, running all the creative, marketing and design companies throughout the Havas network of 300+ offices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/euro-chief-david-jones-oversees-80-havas/134949/ |title=Euro Chief David Jones Now Oversees 80% of Havas | Agency News – Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=27 February 2009 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
From 2007–2010, Jones led the Euro RSCG team advising [[David Cameron]] and the UK [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Silver |first=James |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/organgrinder/2011/mar/14/david-jones-tory-adman-enjoys-going-for-the-jugular |title=David Jones: the Tory ad-man who enjoys going for the jugular | James Silver | Media |publisher=The Guardian |date= 14 March 2011|accessdate=8 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
In 2011, Jones expanded his position to encompass the entire Havas network, including [[Havas Media]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/global-news/david-jones-named-ceo-havas-group/149283/ |title=David Jones Named CEO of Havas Group | News – Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> and was named CEO of Havas.
In 2014 Jones left Havas and one year later he raised $350m and launched a new 'brandtech' group under the name "You & Mr. Jones". <ref>[http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2016/02/15/new-york-says-shalom-to-israeli-startups/ Mark Sweney (11 June 2015). "Ex-Havas chief David Jones raises $350m for new 'brandtech' group". The Guardian. Retrieved March 6th 2017.]</ref>
==Change leadership== David Jones is creator of the "Social Business Idea"—a principle and practice that "operates at the intersection of social responsibility and social media" and "aligns the goals of doing well and doing good."<ref name="amazon1"/> He cites the [[Dulux Let's Colour Project]] as an example.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letscolourproject.com/ |title=Home – Let's Colour Project |publisher=Letscolourproject.com |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> Social Business Ideas are a focus of Jones' book, Who Cares Wins: Why Good Business Is Better Business, scheduled to be published by Pearson/FT Publishing in late 2011. At [[Mashable]] Connect 2011 and other forums, Jones has advocated using the communication skills of the advertising industry to drive social change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2011/06/01/david-jones-connect-keynote/ |title=5 Key Shifts Happening Right Now in the World of Digital Marketing |publisher=Mashable.com |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> He told [[Adweek]] "I passionately believe that what our industry actually excels at is using our creativity to change people's behavior. Given the state of the world, I believe that we in the creative industries not only have an opportunity but an obligation to use that talent and our creativity to change people's behavior around some of the bigger issues facing the world."<ref>{{cite web|last=Chapman |first=Mike |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/beds-are-burning-climate-change-100485 |title='Beds Are Burning' for Climate Change |publisher=Adweek |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2009, Jones co-founded youth forum [[One Young World]], called "arguably the most forward-looking and comprehensive piece of corporate social responsibility ever attempted"<ref>{{cite web|last=Choueke |first=Mark |url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/collaborative-approach-marks-new-age-of-csr/3003613.article |title=Collaborative approach marks new age of CSR | News |publisher=Marketing Week |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> by [[Marketing Week]]. In 2011, Jones' work with One Young World was recognised by the [[Clinton Foundation#Clinton Global Initiative .28CGI.29|Clinton Global Initiative.]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Young |first=One |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/oneyoungworld/5035426813 |title=David Jones receiving Clinton Global Initiative for One Young World | Flickr – Photo Sharing! |publisher=Flickr |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
In advance of the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] in Copenhagen in 2009, Jones was asked by former U.N. Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]] to create a campaign to communicate the urgent need for action. Jones drove the creation of the TckTckTck Campaign for Climate Justice, an open source campaign that recruited more than 17 million "climate allies" to the cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tcktcktck.org/ |title=The Global Campaign for Climate Action : The Global Campaign for Climate Action |publisher=Tcktcktck.org |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> In 2010 TckTckTck was short-listed for a [[Webby Award]] for world's best advocacy campaign,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?season=14 |title=Webby Nominees |publisher=Webbyawards.com |date=28 October 2011 |accessdate=8 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421181147/http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?season=14 |archivedate=21 April 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> and listed by [[The Guardian]] as one of the Top 50 climate tweeters in the world.<ref>{{cite news|last=Edwards |first=Rhiannon |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2010/may/11/top-50-twitter-climate-accounts |title=Top 50 Twitter climate accounts to follow | Environment | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 11 May 2010|accessdate=8 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
==Social Business Idea== In ''Who Cares Wins'', Jones defines the Social Business Idea as the overlap between what a company is good at ("a genuine and credible role for the brand or business"), and what consumers or customers are looking for ("real issues that consumers care about"). He lists as examples [[M·A·C]]'s Viva Glam cosmetics partnering with [[Lady Gaga]] to raise money and awareness for HIV;<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.maccosmetics.com/whats_new/4800/index.tmpl?cm_mmc=Google-_-ENG_ENG%7cVanity%7cProduct%7cPhrase%7cPC-_-M%7cX%7cViva%20Glam%7cX%7cX%7cSPP%7cOK-_-Viva%20Glam |title=MAC Cosmetics: Viva Glam| date= |accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref> [[Levi's]] Water<Less jeans line, produced with lower water usage;<ref>{{cite web|url= http://store.levi.com/waterless |title=Levi's: Water<Less| date= |accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref> [[Marks & Spencer]] "Plan A" environmental commitment;<ref>{{cite web|url= http://plana.marksandspencer.com/ |title=Marks & Spencer: Plan A|date= |accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref> [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] "Better World";<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.nikebetterworld.com/ |title=Nike Better World|date= |accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref> [[Pepsi Refresh Project]],<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.refresheverything.com/ |title=Nike Better World|date= |accessdate=19 December 2011}}</ref> and more.
==Awards and distinctions== The Guardian Sustainable Business Leader 2013
Inducted into [[American Advertising Federation]] "Hall of Achievement" (2005)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aaf.org/default.asp?id=82 |title=AAF-AHOA Members |publisher=Aaf.org |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=8 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111012112407/http://aaf.org/default.asp?id=82 |archivedate=12 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Named to "40 Under 40" list of [[Crain Communications|Crain's New York Business]] (2005)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mycrains.crainsnewyork.com/40under40/profiles/2006/david-jones |title=David Jones – 2006 – 40 Under Forty | Crain's New York Business |publisher=Mycrains.crainsnewyork.com |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
Named to [[Advertising Age]] "40 Under 40" (2006)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/section/special-report-40-under-40/397 |title=Special Report: 40 under 40 – Special Reports – Advertising Age |publisher=Adage.com |date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
[[Financial Times]] and Aviva Top 5 European Pioneering Thought Leaders (2006)
Selected by [[World Economic Forum]] as a Young Global Leader (2008)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20080316115335/World_Economic_Forum_Announces_Euro_RSCG_Worldwides_Global_CEO_David_Jones_as_a_2008_Young_Global_Leader |title=World Economic Forum Announces Euro RSCG Worldwide's Global CEO, David Jones, as a 2008 Young Global Leader |publisher=Zawya |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
Named as number two of two ad industry CEOs of the decade by readers of Adweek (2010)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bestofthe2000s.com/agency-executives-of-the-decade.html |title=AdweekMedia: Best of the 2000s – Agency Executives of the Decade |publisher=Best of the 2000s |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910100704/http://www.bestofthe2000s.com/agency-executives-of-the-decade.html |archivedate=10 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Nominated by CR Magazine as Responsible CEO of the Year (2011)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commitforum.com/index.php/2011/09/08/4th-annual-responsible-ceo-of-the-year-award-nominations-announced |title=4th Annual Responsible CEO of the Year Award Nominations Announced |publisher=Commit Forum |date= |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref>
Founding curator, [[Young Shapers]] (World Economic Forum)
Founding ambassador, [[D&AD|D&AD White Pencil]]
==Earnings==
In 2012, David Jones earned €3,122,654 for its responsibilities within [[Havas]].<ref>[http://www.journaldunet.com/economie/magazine/salaires-patrons/david-jones.shtml SBF 120 executives' earnings], Le Journal du Net, June 25, 2013</ref>
==Personal life== David Jones is married with four young children. He has lived and worked in the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Australia, and the United States.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20110831194007/http://www.eurorscgpress.com/team * http://www.oneyoungworld.com/who-we-are/founders * 20 Questions: David Jones (Financial Times) http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/dcf5a77e-4b48-11e0-b2c2-00144feab49a.html * Havas Chief Talks Outsize Game, Takes on Ad Giants (Advertising Age) http://adage.com/article/agency-news/havas-chief-talks-outsize-game-takes-ad-giants/149378/ * Man on a Mission (Marketing Week) http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/man-on-a-mission/3009162.article

page.title: Effects of the 2008–10 automotive industry crisis on Canada

revision.text:
{{main|Automotive industry crisis of 2008–2010}}
The Canadian auto industry is closely linked to the U.S., due to the [[Automotive Products Trade Agreement]] and later the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA), and is in similar trouble. Canada's 3,500 car dealers, which employ 140,000 people, told the federal and Ontario governments in mid-November they are at risk from the financial crisis; they are asking the national government to help out despite a record year{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} of sales. Ottawa is considering providing financial aid to the Canadian subsidiaries of the Big Three, and possibly auto parts companies as well. The auto industry argued that loan guarantees and other help would try to save tens of thousands of Canadian jobs threatened by the sudden drop in North American car sales. Chrysler Canada has asked for $1 billion in aid, making it the only Canadian arm of the Big Three to make a specific dollar request.
Industry analyst Anthony Faria criticized the labor contracts that [[Canadian Auto Workers]] then-president [[Buzz Hargrove]] negotiated with the [[Big Three automobile manufacturers|Big Three US automobile manufacturers]] in 2007, predicting that the [[subprime mortgage crisis]] and currency would hit Canadian auto production especially hard. Faria noted that [[UAW]] president [[Ron Gettelfinger]] agreed to have the UAW's "all-in" wage, benefit and pension costs drop from a high of $75.86 per hour in 2007 to an average of about $51 per hour starting in 2010. By comparison, the CAW's cost per hour was $77 in 2007 and will rise to over $80 per hour by the end of the new contract. Faria said that Gettelfinger went into negotiations "with the right intention...Save jobs. The CAW strategy was to squeeze every dime out of them."<ref>{{cite web |first=Chris Vander |last=Doelen |url=http://www.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=63a938bc-58fa-4795-9ec4-10741d105193 |title=Thousands of CAW auto job losses predicted |work=The Windsor Star |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2009-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215053440/http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=63a938bc-58fa-4795-9ec4-10741d105193 |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> Hargrove was said to have "instilled backbone and an attitude that the union could always make the auto makers buckle at the bargaining table".<ref name="business.theglobeandmail.com">{{cite web|author=Derek Decloet |url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090309.wdecloet0310/BNStory/robColumnsBlogs/home |title=reportonbusiness.com: Columns and Blogs |publisher=Business.theglobeandmail.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313035141/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090309.wdecloet0310/BNStory/robColumnsBlogs/home |archivedate=2009-03-13 |df= }}</ref>
Current union president [[Ken Lewenza, Sr.|Ken Lewenza]] has argued that labor is not responsible for the bankruptcy crisis facing the Big Three automakers, saying that his members would not make concessions part of any taxpayer-funded bailout. "We don't see this as us being the problem", Lewenza said, adding he would "absolutely not" accept any further cuts after losing tens of thousands of jobs in recent years. "We've suffered our share of pain."<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5grcl5q0uPoqkOoWENxe22Q3dbqwg]{{dead link|date=January 2009}}</ref> Lawenza argued that the CAW agreed in 2007 to make concessions that will save the Big Three $900 million over three years.<ref>"Car dealers plead for government help," [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081121.wcdeals1121/BNStory/National/home ''The Canadian Press'' Nov. 21, 2008 online]; "Labour rates not a problem in auto industry: Lewenza," [http://www.edmontonsun.com/Business/News/2008/11/20/7474801.html Canadian Press, Nov. 20, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081123013323/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081121.wcdeals1121/BNStory/National/home |date=November 23, 2008 }}</ref>
A spokesman for the [[Canadian Taxpayers Federation]] has criticized the CAW's "no-concession" stance, saying that it only serves to strengthen the opposition to a taxpayer-funded bailout for the struggling Detroit Three automakers. The CTF further pointed out that "It is especially difficult to understand anyone asking for government help that refuses to do anything to help itself to begin with", since they "fail to realize they've existed at the substantial largesse of taxpayers for decades".<ref>{{cite web |first=Grace |last=Macaluso |url=http://www.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=c07f9882-2f99-4479-b067-831ac302129a |title=Lewenza 'petulant' child |work=The Windsor Star |publisher=Canada.com |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2009-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215051012/http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=c07f9882-2f99-4479-b067-831ac302129a |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> Kelly McParland, a columnist for the [[National Post]], has suggested that "if he won't give anything, he and his members are likely to lose everything." He also said that the problem facing the North American auto industry was borne equally by management and labor alike, criticizing labor for building up pay and benefits for themselves that was as unsustainable as it was enviable, while attacking management for its short-term strategy of selling gas-guzzling trucks and sales tactics (price cuts, rebates, free gas and cash-back schemes).<ref>{{cite web|first=Kelly |last=McParland |url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/fullcomment/archive/2008/11/19/kelly-mcparland-stop-the-revolution-the-caw-wants-to-get-off.aspx |title=Kelly McParland: Stop the revolution, the CAW wants to get off |publisher=National Post |date=November 19, 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-12 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The CTF has opposed the proposed $3.5 CAD billion bailout for Canadian subsidiaries of the Big Three, saying that it was an unfair financial burden on the average Canadian, as well as another excuse for the Detroit automakers to postpone much needed change. The CTF noted that federal and provincial governments spent $782-million in the past five years on the Big Three, saying "These have been a bottomless pit of requests for cash". Lewenza disagreed, saying that the bailout should be seen by Canadians as a loan that will be paid back when the country's economy is prosperous again.<ref>{{cite news|first=Linda |last=Nguyen |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/story.html?id=1073285 |title=Canadian taxpayers and auto union butt heads over bailout |agency=Canwest News Service |publisher=National Post |date=2008-12-13 |accessdate=2009-01-12 |df= }}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
On December 20, the government of Canada and the province of [[Ontario]] offered $3.3 billion in loans to the auto industry. Under the plan [[General Motors|GM]] will receive $3 billion and [[Chrysler]] will receive the rest. [[Ford]] only asked for a line of credit but will not be participating in the bailout.<ref>{{cite news|last=Austen |first=Ian |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/business/worldbusiness/21canada.html?ref=business |title=Canada Agrees to Its Own Auto Industry Bailout |location=Canada |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2008-12-20 |accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref>
The CAW negotiated a cost-cutting deal with General Motors Canada on March 8, 2009. The deal would extend the current contract for an additional year to September 2012, and preserves the current average assembly-worker base pay of about $34 an hour. It would eliminate a $1,700 annual "special bonus," and reduce special paid absences or "SPA days" from two weeks to one week a year, while maintaining vacation entitlements which range up to six weeks a year for high-seniority workers. The deal also introduce payments by members toward their health benefits - $30 monthly per family for workers and $15 a month for pensioners. Lewenza said it also would trim by 35 per cent company contributions to union-provided programs such as child care and wellness programs. Lewenza called the package a "major sacrifice." However, observers noted that the deal did not go far enough; DBRS analyst Kam Hon described it as "not material." Automotive industry consultant [[Dennis DesRosiers]] said that General Motors had missed the chance to slash labour costs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lfpress.ca/newsstand/CityandRegion/2009/03/09/8687446.html |title=London Free Press - City & Region - GM missed the boat, auto analyst says |publisher=Lfpress.ca |date=2009-03-09 |accessdate=2009-05-01}}{{dead link|date=November 2009}}</ref> pointing out that bankruptcy was a looming threat, Ottawa and Queen's Park demanded cuts to the labour bill as a condition of the bailout, and that the deficit to the pension fund would prevent the CAW from striking.<ref name="business.theglobeandmail.com"/> He estimated the total hourly cost of a GM Canada worker, including benefits, is $75 to $78, and saying that "they [GM] got six or seven" when it should have been cut by $20. DesRosiers also said giving up cost-of-living increases is not significant when inflation is nearly non-existent and added that the 40-hour reduction in [[paid time off]] merely means "five fewer spa days." [[University of Toronto]] professor Joe D'Cruz calculated that it would save $148 million a year, though GM is seeking $6 billion in Canadian government support. <ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5hj8fbrVBMQeu70Pw38EaSxlnTpsg ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313013144/https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5hj8fbrVBMQeu70Pw38EaSxlnTpsg |date=March 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.am770chqr.com/News/Business/Article.aspx?id=92681 |title=AM 770: News. Talk. Sports. - Business News |publisher=Am770chqr.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-01 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> CAW autoworkers with seniority were able to maintain 10 weeks of vacation with full pay, while not contributing to their pension fund, relying instead on taxpayers (including these without pensions) to help make up their unfunded liabilities.<ref name="financialpost2">{{cite web |author=national post Published: Thursday, March 05, 2009 |url=http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1357929 |title=Only CAW can save Ottawa from bailout |publisher=Financialpost.com |date=2009-03-05 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090410073430/http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1357929 |archivedate=2009-04-10 |df= }}</ref>
The agreement is contingent on Canada being allocated 20% of GM's North American, and getting billions of dollars in federal and provincial taxpayer support, which Lewenza stressed will be loans. However, some suggested that this would not be the final time that automakers would request a bailout.<ref name="financialpost1">{{cite web |url=http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1343240 |title=John Ivison: Automotive bailout must not be free ride |publisher=Financialpost.com |date=2009-03-02 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402161023/http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1343240 |archivedate=2009-04-02 |df= }}</ref> Dennis DesRosiers estimated that GM will go through its government loans in a couple of quarters, long before any recovery in the market. Furthermore, GM Canada president Arturo Elias had admitted to MP [[Frank Valeriote]] that GM had pledged all its assets worldwide to the U.S. government in order to secure the first [[tranche]] of a US$30-billion loan, leaving no assets to collateralize the $6 billion loan from the Canadian government. The Canadian Taxpayers' Federation noted that between 1982 and 2005, Ottawa handed out over $18.2 billion to corporations, of which only $7.1 billion was repayable, and only $1.3 billion was ever repaid. <ref name="financialpost2"/>
Chrysler vice-chairman and president [[Thomas W. LaSorda]] (himself the son of a CAW official) and Ford's chief of manufacturing Joe Hinrichs said that the GM-CAW deal was insufficient, suggesting that they would break the CAW's negotiating pattern set by GM. LaSorda told the [[House of Commons of Canada]] finance committee that he would demand an hourly wage cut of $20, suggested that Chrysler may withdraw from Canada if it fails to achieve more substantial cost savings from the CAW. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/CAWkeen+extend+GMdeal+Ford+Chrysler/1394268/story.html |title=CAWkeen to extend GMdeal to Ford, Chrysler |publisher=Canada.com |date=2009-03-15 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128214155/http://www.canada.com/CAWkeen+extend+GMdeal+Ford+Chrysler/1394268/story.html |archivedate=2016-01-28 |df= }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=atjPPT9kXqAY&refer=home |title=GM Says CAW Union Pact Wins Parity With U.S. Foreign Automakers |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=2009-03-14 |accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/privateEquity/idUSN1650804820090316 |title=RPT-Chrysler Canada cannot afford GM-CAW deal -source | Deals | Private Capital |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-03-16 |accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref>
On March 31, 2009, the Canadian federal and Ontario governments jointly rejected the restructuring plans submitted by GM and Chrysler. This came a day after US President [[Barack Obama]] had rejected the plans of their parent companies. Both federal Industry Minister [[Tony Clement]] and Ontario Premier [[Dalton McGuinty]] suggested the CAW's initial deal was insufficient in cutting costs and the union had return to the bargaining table to make further concessions, in order to show that taxpayers' money is justified. <ref>{{cite web|author=Greg Keenan And Karen Howlett |url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090331.wgm0331/BNStory/Business/home |title=reportonbusiness.com: Find more cuts, Premier tells GM and CAW |publisher=Business.theglobeandmail.com |date=2009-03-31 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403150353/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090331.wgm0331/BNStory/Business/home |archivedate=2009-04-03 |df= }}</ref> As well, [[Fiat]] CEO [[Sergio Marchionne]] has asked that the CAW's wages be reduced to the levels of non-unionized workers from Honda and Toyota operating in Canada, or else they would walk away from the [[Fiat#Partnership with Chrysler|proposed alliance with Chrysler]], resulting in the latter being forced into bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite web |author=Eric Reguly And Greg Keenan |url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090414.wrfiat15/BNStory/Business/home |title=reportonbusiness.com: Fiat to Chrysler: Cut costs or we walk |location=Rome And Toronto |publisher=Business.theglobeandmail.com |date=2009-04-15 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418172951/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090414.wrfiat15/BNStory/Business/home |archivedate=2009-04-18 |df= }}</ref>
On May 14, 2018, the Canadian federal government announced it would fall short of breaking even from the bailouts of Chrysler Group LLC and General Motors Co. by $3.5 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/canadian-taxpayers-lose-35-billion-on-2009-bailout-of-auto-firms/article23828543/|title=Canadian taxpayers lose $3.5-billion on 2009 bailout of auto firms|publisher=''The Globe and Mail''|date=May 14, 2018|last=Siu|first=Michelle|accessdate=2018-06-29}}</ref> On June 26, 2018, the remaining undisclosed loan amount was written off.<ref name="CBC180626">{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/loans-canada-account-finance-auto-sector-bailout-2009-gm-chrysler-1.4722529|title=Federal government quietly writes off loan — but won't reveal sum or say who got it|publisher=''CBC News''|date=June 26, 2018|last=Beeby|first=Dean|accessdate=2018-06-29}}</ref> The [[Fraser Institute]] estimates the total cost to taxpayers at $3.7 billion that was never repaid.<ref name="CBC180626" />
==See also== *[[Automotive industry crisis of 2008–2010]] *[[Chrysler bankruptcy]] *[[Effects of the 2008–2010 automotive industry crisis on the United States]] *[[General Motors bankruptcy]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
